item.title: Celebrate the Moscow metro's 80th birthday with a journey through the city's history
item.trailText: When it opened on 15 May 1935, the Moscow metro was a subterranean Communist paradise: its chandeliers, marble, intricate mosaics and heroic statues created an opulent space that was accessible for the city’s workers. Eighty years on it transports up to nine million people a day, with expansion plans set to make it the world’s fourth largest subway system by 2020
item.standFirst: When it opened on 15 May 1935, the Moscow metro was a subterranean Communist paradise: its chandeliers, marble, intricate mosaics and heroic statues created an opulent space that was accessible for the city’s workers. Eighty years on, it transports up to nine million people a day, with expansion plans set to make it the world’s fourth largest subway system by 2020

displayImages.caption: The first designs for Moscow’s metro were submitted to city authorities under the reign of Tsar Nicholas II in 1902. Moscow wanted to rival earlier systems in London, Paris and Berlin (New York’s opened in 1904) – but the Russian city’s plans were repeatedly derailed: by the uprising of 1905, the first world war and the Bolshevik revolution of 1917. Metro plans were finally approved under Joseph Stalin in 1931 and construction work is pictured here two years later Photograph: Alamy
displayImages.altText: Construction of the Moscow Metro, October 1933
displayImages.cleanCaption: The first designs for Moscow’s metro were submitted to city authorities under the reign of Tsar Nicholas II in 1902. Moscow wanted to rival earlier systems in London, Paris and Berlin (New York’s opened in 1904) – but the Russian city’s plans were repeatedly derailed: by the uprising of 1905, the first world war and the Bolshevik revolution of 1917. Metro plans were finally approved under Joseph Stalin in 1931 and construction work is pictured here two years later

displayImages.caption: The first line ran from Sokolniki (Соко́льники) to Dvorets Sovetov. Soviet workers carried out the construction under ‘Iron Commissar’ Lazar Kaganovich – at the cost of many lives – but the engineers were from the London Underground. Stalin’s secret police arrested many on espionage charges – apparently they had gained a dangerous knowledge of the subway and the city’s layout – and they were deported in 1933 after a show trial. Architect Charles Holden was one of the advisers, and the barrel-vaulted hall he built at Gants Hill on the Central Line echoes the standard Moscow station design Photograph: Alamy
displayImages.altText: The Moscow Metro’s first train run, October 1934
displayImages.cleanCaption: The first line ran from Sokolniki (Соко́льники) to Dvorets Sovetov. Soviet workers carried out the construction under ‘Iron Commissar’ Lazar Kaganovich – at the cost of many lives – but the engineers were from the London Underground. Stalin’s secret police arrested many on espionage charges – apparently they had gained a dangerous knowledge of the subway and the city’s layout – and they were deported in 1933 after a show trial. Architect Charles Holden was one of the advisers, and the barrel-vaulted hall he built at Gants Hill on the Central Line echoes the standard Moscow station design

displayImages.caption: An estimated 285,000 people rode the Moscow metro on the day it opened, 15 May 1935. Its construction was hailed as a technological and ideological triumph for socialism and Stalinism. After witnessing its first days, the German poet and playwright Bertholt Brecht wrote: ‘Now that the railway was built in accordance with the most perfect plans/ And the owners came to view it and/ To ride on it, they were the selfsame people/ Who had built it.’ Pictured: workers take the first ride Photograph: Ivan Shagin/Slava Katamidze Collection/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: After the completion of Moscow’s first underground line, workers take the first ride in the new train, 1935
displayImages.cleanCaption: An estimated 285,000 people rode the Moscow metro on the day it opened, 15 May 1935. Its construction was hailed as a technological and ideological triumph for socialism and Stalinism. After witnessing its first days, the German poet and playwright Bertholt Brecht wrote: ‘Now that the railway was built in accordance with the most perfect plans/ And the owners came to view it and/ To ride on it, they were the selfsame people/ Who had built it.’ Pictured: workers take the first ride
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Ivan Shagin/Slava Katamidze Collection/Getty Images

displayImages.caption: A huge portrait of Vladimir Lenin at Biblioteka Imeni Lenina – one of the first metro stations to open Photograph: Kirill Kudryatsev/AFP
displayImages.altText: Subway passengers walk past a huge portrait of the Soviet Union founder Vladimir Lenin in a vestibule of the Biblioteka Imeni Lenina metro station in Moscow.
displayImages.cleanCaption: A huge portrait of Vladimir Lenin at Biblioteka Imeni Lenina – one of the first metro stations to open

displayImages.caption: Dvorets Sovetov, another in the first batch of stations, was named after Stalin’s planned Palace of the Soviets. The building – on the site of the demolished Cathedral of Christ the Saviour – was to be the tallest structure in the world and topped with a 100-metre statue of Lenin. The station was decorated with marble from the cathedral, but plans for the palace were scuppered by the second world war and it was never built. The station was renamed Kropotkinskaya in the 1950s after anarchist Peter Kropotkin, who was born nearby. The cathedral was rebuilt after the collapse of the Soviet Union Photograph: Mikhail Shcherbakov/Wikimedia Commons
displayImages.cleanCaption: Dvorets Sovetov, another in the first batch of stations, was named after Stalin’s planned Palace of the Soviets. The building – on the site of the demolished Cathedral of Christ the Saviour – was to be the tallest structure in the world and topped with a 100-metre statue of Lenin. The station was decorated with marble from the cathedral, but plans for the palace were scuppered by the second world war and it was never built. The station was renamed Kropotkinskaya in the 1950s after anarchist Peter Kropotkin, who was born nearby. The cathedral was rebuilt after the collapse of the Soviet Union

displayImages.caption: Ploshchad Revolutsii was among the stations opened in 1938, the second stage of the metro. It features 76 bronze sculptures by Matvey Manizer depicting the creators of the new Socialist order: including farmers, workers, soldiers and athletes. Many stations from the Stalin era have Socialist Realist themes, conforming to Nikolay Chernyshevsky’s maxim that ‘art is no use unless it serves politics’ Photograph: Linda Nylind/Guardian
displayImages.altText: A woman waits on a platform at Ploshchad Revolutsii metro station.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Ploshchad Revolutsii was among the stations opened in 1938, the second stage of the metro. It features 76 bronze sculptures by Matvey Manizer depicting the creators of the new Socialist order: including farmers, workers, soldiers and athletes. Many stations from the Stalin era have Socialist Realist themes, conforming to Nikolay Chernyshevsky’s maxim that ‘art is no use unless it serves politics’

displayImages.caption: Mayakovskaya station – with its art deco stainless steel columns – was built in the same year. Each niche in the ceiling features a different mosaic by Aleksandr Deyneka Photograph: Gary Hershorn/Reuters
displayImages.altText: A man walks through the Mayakovskaya subway station in Moscow.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Mayakovskaya station – with its art deco stainless steel columns – was built in the same year. Each niche in the ceiling features a different mosaic by Aleksandr Deyneka

displayImages.caption: One of the 34 Alexander Deyneka mosiacs in the ceiling at Mayakovskaya station: together forming a work known as 24-hour Soviet Sky Photograph: Alamy
displayImages.altText: Detail of a ceiling mural at Mayakovskaya Station
displayImages.cleanCaption: One of the 34 Alexander Deyneka mosiacs in the ceiling at Mayakovskaya station: together forming a work known as 24-hour Soviet Sky

displayImages.caption: Mayakovskaya metro station was used as a bomb shelter during the second world war, known as the ‘great patriotic war’ in Russia. Stalin made a speech in the station in November 1941 to celebrate the 24th anniversary of Bolshevik revolution, as the Nazis bombarded the city above Photograph: Alamy
displayImages.altText: Peoplwe shelter in the underground hall of Mayakovskaya Moscow metro station, October 1941
displayImages.cleanCaption: Mayakovskaya metro station was used as a bomb shelter during the second world war, known as the ‘great patriotic war’ in Russia. Stalin made a speech in the station in November 1941 to celebrate the 24th anniversary of Bolshevik revolution, as the Nazis bombarded the city above

displayImages.caption: Work on the Moscow metro’s third stage was delayed – but not stopped – by the war. Elektrozavodskaya station, named after a nearby lightbulb factory, was opened in 1944 Photograph: Rick Gerharter/Getty Images/Lonely Planet Images
displayImages.altText: A platform in Elektrozavodskaya metro station
displayImages.cleanCaption: Work on the Moscow metro’s third stage was delayed – but not stopped – by the war. Elektrozavodskaya station, named after a nearby lightbulb factory, was opened in 1944
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Rick Gerharter/Getty Images/Lonely Planet Images

displayImages.caption: Crowds at the opening of Komsomolskaya station in 1952, part of the metro’s fourth stage. The station is decorated with Pavel Morin murals inspired by the speech Stalin gave in November 1941, when he invoked Alexander Nevsky and other historical heroes to inspire the Russian people as they struggled under catastrophic losses in the early part of the war Photograph: Bettmann/Corbis
displayImages.altText: Crowds at the Komsomolskaya-Ring station of the Moscow Metro, to mark the opening of a new section. All 39 stations have works of architecture and fine arts
displayImages.cleanCaption: Crowds at the opening of Komsomolskaya station in 1952, part of the metro’s fourth stage. The station is decorated with Pavel Morin murals inspired by the speech Stalin gave in November 1941, when he invoked Alexander Nevsky and other historical heroes to inspire the Russian people as they struggled under catastrophic losses in the early part of the war

displayImages.caption: Komsomolskaya station – a baroque ‘palace of the people’ – is often considered the zenith of High Stalinist metro design. It remains ‘a symbolic expression of the magnificent results of the proletarian dictatorship’ Photograph: Graham Lawrence/Getty Images/Robert Harding
displayImages.cleanCaption: Komsomolskaya station – a baroque ‘palace of the people’ – is often considered the zenith of High Stalinist metro design. It remains ‘a symbolic expression of the magnificent results of the proletarian dictatorship’

displayImages.caption: Pavel Morin also composed the artwork for the stained glass panels at Novoslobodskaya station, renovated back to its 1950s glory a decade ago Photograph: Kirill Kudryavtsev/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Subway passengers stand on the platfrom at the Novoslobodskaya metro station, April 2014
displayImages.cleanCaption: Pavel Morin also composed the artwork for the stained glass panels at Novoslobodskaya station, renovated back to its 1950s glory a decade ago

displayImages.caption: Kiyevskaya metro station – also on the Koltsevaya ‘ring line’ with Komsomolskaya and Novoslobodskaya – opened in 1954. Lighting in the metro was designed to create atmosphere rather than be purely functional Photograph: Linda Nylind/Guardian
displayImages.cleanCaption: Kiyevskaya metro station – also on the Koltsevaya ‘ring line’ with Komsomolskaya and Novoslobodskaya – opened in 1954. Lighting in the metro was designed to create atmosphere rather than be purely functional

displayImages.caption: Mosaics and murals in Kiyevskaya station depict Russo-Ukrainian unity Photograph: Alamy
displayImages.altText: A fresco depicting Ukraine in the Kyevskaya metro station
displayImages.cleanCaption: Mosaics and murals in Kiyevskaya station depict Russo-Ukrainian unity

displayImages.caption: The large statue of Stalin in the vestibule at Kurskaya station was removed in the 1960s – but the lines from the anthem of the Soviet Union were renovated a few years ago: ‘Stalin brought us up on loyalty to the people … [and] … inspired us to labour and to heroism’ Photograph: Ivan Sekretarev/AP
displayImages.altText: A line from the lyrics of the Soviet anthem glorifying Josef Stalin and reading “Stalin brought us up on loyalty to the people” and “inspired us to labour and to heroism” was restored in 2009 to the vestibule of the Kurskaya metro station
displayImages.cleanCaption: The large statue of Stalin in the vestibule at Kurskaya station was removed in the 1960s – but the lines from the anthem of the Soviet Union were renovated a few years ago: ‘Stalin brought us up on loyalty to the people … [and] … inspired us to labour and to heroism’

displayImages.caption: After Stalin’s death in 1953, new leader Nikita Khrushchev condemned the excesses and ‘unnecessary luxury’ of the past. VDNKh station, started in the early 50s, was to be richly decorated with mosaics by Vladimir Favorsky along the insides of the arches – but Khrushchev’s crackdown led to the mosaics being covered with coats of thick green paint. The metro was to enter a more sober period under the slogan: ‘Kilometres at the expense of architecture’ Photograph: A Savin/Wikimedia Commons
displayImages.cleanCaption: After Stalin’s death in 1953, new leader Nikita Khrushchev condemned the excesses and ‘unnecessary luxury’ of the past. VDNKh station, started in the early 50s, was to be richly decorated with mosaics by Vladimir Favorsky along the insides of the arches – but Khrushchev’s crackdown led to the mosaics being covered with coats of thick green paint. The metro was to enter a more sober period under the slogan: ‘Kilometres at the expense of architecture’

displayImages.caption: Tverskaya – opened in 1979 – is typical of the style of the 60s and 70s. Stations from this period were built more cheaply and many look almost identical Photograph: Mikhail Shcherbakov/Wikimedia Commons
displayImages.cleanCaption: Tverskaya – opened in 1979 – is typical of the style of the 60s and 70s. Stations from this period were built more cheaply and many look almost identical

displayImages.caption: Passengers on the Moscow metro in 1992 Photograph: Alamy
displayImages.altText: Passengers in a packed Moscow Metro train, November 1992
displayImages.cleanCaption: Passengers on the Moscow metro in 1992

displayImages.caption: Rimskaya station opened in 1995, three years after the collapse of the Soviet Union. It is named after the Italian capital, and its sculptures of Romulus and Remus sitting atop fallen columns ostensibly represent the mythical founders of Rome. Some commentators, however, saw parallels with a more recently collapsed empire Photograph: John Lander/Alamy
displayImages.altText: Romulus and Remus sculptures in Rimskaya Station, 2006
displayImages.cleanCaption: Rimskaya station opened in 1995, three years after the collapse of the Soviet Union. It is named after the Italian capital, and its sculptures of Romulus and Remus sitting atop fallen columns ostensibly represent the mythical founders of Rome. Some commentators, however, saw parallels with a more recently collapsed empire

displayImages.caption: A mosaic in Park Pobedy (Victory Park) station celebrates the winning of the great patriotic war in 1945. The station was opened in 2003, marking a return to what has been called a neo-Stalinist style Photograph: Alamy
displayImages.altText: Wall mosaic celebrating the victory in 1945, in Park Pobedy metro station
displayImages.cleanCaption: A mosaic in Park Pobedy (Victory Park) station celebrates the winning of the great patriotic war in 1945. The station was opened in 2003, marking a return to what has been called a neo-Stalinist style

displayImages.caption: Flowers left in memory of the victims of a bomb explosion at Park Kultury metro station in March 2010. Two female suicide bombers killed 40 people in rush-hour attacks there and at Lubyanka. They were the first bombings on the metro since 2004, when 41 people were killed by a suicide bomber in February and 10 more died in a blast in August Photograph: Denis Sinyakov/Reuters
displayImages.altText: Flowers left in memory of the victims of a bomb explosion at Park Kultury metro station in March 2010. Two female suicide bombers killed 40 people in rush-hour attacks there and at Lubyanka. They were the first bombings on the metro since 2004, when 41 people were killed by a suicide bomber in February and 10 more died in a blast in August.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Flowers left in memory of the victims of a bomb explosion at Park Kultury metro station in March 2010. Two female suicide bombers killed 40 people in rush-hour attacks there and at Lubyanka. They were the first bombings on the metro since 2004, when 41 people were killed by a suicide bomber in February and 10 more died in a blast in August

displayImages.caption: Dostoyevskaya metro station opened in May 2010 to celebrate the metro’s 75th birthday. It features black and white panels of the author Fyodor Dostoyevsky and characters from his novels The Idiot, Crime and Punishment and the Brothers Karamazov by artist Ivan Nikolayev Photograph: Kirill Kudryavtsev/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: The Dostoyevskaya metro station with a mural of Russian writer Fyodor Dostoyevsky
displayImages.cleanCaption: Dostoyevskaya metro station opened in May 2010 to celebrate the metro’s 75th birthday. It features black and white panels of the author Fyodor Dostoyevsky and characters from his novels The Idiot, Crime and Punishment and the Brothers Karamazov by artist Ivan Nikolayev

displayImages.caption: Lubyanka (Лубянка) is home to the Russian security service the FSB, and is also rumoured to lead to a secret subway system built by Stalin deeper than the public lines. The Metro-2 network, apparently codenamed D6 by the KGB, is thought to have been constructed to connect key strategic buildings and allow the evacuation of high-ranking personnel in the event of a nuclear attack. Its existence has never been confirmed, but urban explorers the Diggers claimed they found an entrance to the system in 1994 Photograph: Reuters
displayImages.altText: A sign that reads "Lubyanka" is seen through a window of a moving train at Lubyanka metro station in Moscow March 30, 2010. Moscow observed an official day of mourning on Tuesday and nervous commuters returned to the metro, while the death toll from twin suicide bombings on the capital's underground railway rose by one to 39 people.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Lubyanka (Лубянка) is home to the Russian security service the FSB, and is also rumoured to lead to a secret subway system built by Stalin deeper than the public lines. The Metro-2 network, apparently codenamed D6 by the KGB, is thought to have been constructed to connect key strategic buildings and allow the evacuation of high-ranking personnel in the event of a nuclear attack. Its existence has never been confirmed, but urban explorers the Diggers claimed they found an entrance to the system in 1994

displayImages.caption: Moscow metro riders enjoy free Wi-Fi. A journey anywhere costs 30 roubles (about 50p) Photograph: Smertin Pavel/Itar-Tass/Corbis
displayImages.altText: People using their tablets on a Moscow metro train.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Moscow metro riders enjoy free Wi-Fi. A journey anywhere costs 30 roubles (about 50p)

displayImages.caption: The Moscow metro is expanding fast. Myakinino station was the first to be built under a public-private partnership, with financing from Baku-born billionaire Aras Agalarov who wanted a stop at his Crocus shopping mall and trade expo centre. Strogino (pictured) was the 175th station when it opened seven years ago; this month the metro will mark 80 years with another new station, its 200th, at Kotelniki. Thirty-five new stops are planned to open over the next three years, and 75 miles of new track will make Moscow the world’s fourth largest after Seoul, Shanghai and Beijing Photograph: Mikhail Metzel/AP
displayImages.altText: Commuters walk through Moscow's Strogino metro station in 2008.
displayImages.cleanCaption: The Moscow metro is expanding fast. Myakinino station was the first to be built under a public-private partnership, with financing from Baku-born billionaire Aras Agalarov who wanted a stop at his Crocus shopping mall and trade expo centre. Strogino (pictured) was the 175th station when it opened seven years ago; this month the metro will mark 80 years with another new station, its 200th, at Kotelniki. Thirty-five new stops are planned to open over the next three years, and 75 miles of new track will make Moscow the world’s fourth largest after Seoul, Shanghai and Beijing

cards.title: World's worst commute / Chinese police discover 50 people travelling in minivan
cards.rawTitle: Chinese police discover 50 people travelling in minivan

item.title: Chinese police discover 50 people travelling in mini van
item.trailText: Police discover a six-seater van with 50 people, including the driver, crammed inside in the southern Chinese city of Guiyang
item.standFirst: Police discover a six-seater van with 50 people, including the driver, crammed inside in the southern Chinese city of Guiyang. The footage shows a police officer counting the passengers as they stream out. They are workers at a local construction site and were asked to pack in to reduce commuting time. They were reportedly transferred to other vehicles and their driver given a fine

stillImage.caption: A van in China found to be carrying 50 people on the commute to a construction site. 14 May 2015 Photograph: Reuters Photograph: Reuters
stillImage.cleanCaption: A van in China found to be carrying 50 people on the commute to a construction site. 14 May 2015 Photograph: Reuters

displayImages.caption: A van in China found to be carrying 50 people on the commute to a construction site. 14 May 2015 Photograph: Reuters Photograph: Reuters
displayImages.cleanCaption: A van in China found to be carrying 50 people on the commute to a construction site. 14 May 2015 Photograph: Reuters

cards.title: Venice Biennale / Must-see art from the 'new east'

item.title: Venice Biennale: must-see art from the 'new east'
item.trailText: As Armenia wins Golden Lion for best national pavilion, The Calvert Journal picks the most exciting artists from eastern Europe and former Soviet Union
item.standFirst: As Armenia wins Golden Lion for best national pavilion, The Calvert Journal picks the most exciting artists from eastern Europe and former Soviet Union
item.byline: ​Dina Akhmadeeva for The Calvert Journal, part of the New East network

displayImages.caption:
Aikaterini Gegisian, Armenia
Representing Armenia, Gegisian has sourced photographs of cities from the 1960s–1980s that he collages together to create new and imagined places. The exhibition was awarded the prestigious Golden Lion, and its participants – artists and the grandchildren of Armenian genocide survivors – were praised by the jury for ‘forming a pavilion based on a people in diaspora, each artist engaging their specific locality as well as their heritage’ Photograph: Aikaterini Gegisian, Kalfayan Galleries, The Calvert Journal
displayImages.credit: Aikaterini Gegisian, Kalfayan Galleries, The Calvert Journal
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Aikaterini Gegisian, Armenia
Representing Armenia, Gegisian has sourced photographs of cities from the 1960s–1980s that he collages together to create new and imagined places. The exhibition was awarded the prestigious Golden Lion, and its participants – artists and the grandchildren of Armenian genocide survivors – were praised by the jury for ‘forming a pavilion based on a people in diaspora, each artist engaging their specific locality as well as their heritage’
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Aikaterini Gegisian, Kalfayan Galleries, The Calvert Journal

displayImages.caption:
Jaanus Samma, Estonia
Samma has spent years working with archival material detailing the silenced histories of Estonian homosexuals during the Soviet-era. For the biennale, Samma presents a series of photographs of Juhan Ojaste (1921-90), the chairman of a collective farm deemed ‘unsuitable for work’ because of his sexuality Photograph: G. Paas, Estonian Film Archives, The Calvert Journal
displayImages.credit: G. Paas, Estonian Film Archives, The Calvert Journal
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Jaanus Samma, Estonia
Samma has spent years working with archival material detailing the silenced histories of Estonian homosexuals during the Soviet-era. For the biennale, Samma presents a series of photographs of Juhan Ojaste (1921-90), the chairman of a collective farm deemed ‘unsuitable for work’ because of his sexuality
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: G. Paas, Estonian Film Archives, The Calvert Journal

displayImages.caption:
CT Jasper and Joanna Malinowska, Poland
When in 1802 Napoleon sent his Polish soldiers to quell a rebellion in French-occupied Haiti, they ended up fighting successfully for Haitian independence. Descendants of Polish Haitians – who were given citizenship as a result – still exist. In their work presented at the Polish pavilion, Jasper and Malinowska explore the links between the two countries Photograph: Barbara Kaja Kaniewska, Mateusz Golis/The Calvert Journal
displayImages.credit: Barbara Kaja Kaniewska, Mateusz Golis/The Calvert Journal
displayImages.cleanCaption:
CT Jasper and Joanna Malinowska, Poland
When in 1802 Napoleon sent his Polish soldiers to quell a rebellion in French-occupied Haiti, they ended up fighting successfully for Haitian independence. Descendants of Polish Haitians – who were given citizenship as a result – still exist. In their work presented at the Polish pavilion, Jasper and Malinowska explore the links between the two countries
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Barbara Kaja Kaniewska, Mateusz Golis/The Calvert Journal

displayImages.caption:
Askhat Akhmediyarov, Kazakhstan
This year, there is no Central Asian pavilion at the biennale. Instead, the International Art Development Association is showcasing a group exhibition of contemporary Kazakh art. In this image, artist Askhat Akhmediyarov addresses the seeping of modernity – television, consumerism, urbanisation – into ‘traditional’ Kazakhstan Photograph: The Calvert Journal
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Askhat Akhmediyarov, Kazakhstan
This year, there is no Central Asian pavilion at the biennale. Instead, the International Art Development Association is showcasing a group exhibition of contemporary Kazakh art. In this image, artist Askhat Akhmediyarov addresses the seeping of modernity – television, consumerism, urbanisation – into ‘traditional’ Kazakhstan

displayImages.caption:
Konstantin Selikhanov, Belarus
A project by the Minsk Centre of Photography, the Belarusian pavilion presents War Witness Archive, a series of images and testimonies from world war one which curator Aleksei Shinkarenko says question ‘what it means to witness an historic event today’
Photograph: The Calvert Journal
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Konstantin Selikhanov, Belarus
A project by the Minsk Centre of Photography, the Belarusian pavilion presents War Witness Archive, a series of images and testimonies from world war one which curator Aleksei Shinkarenko says question ‘what it means to witness an historic event today’

displayImages.caption:
Almagul Menlibayeva, Azerbaijan
Menlibayeva draws on long-forgotten links between Venice and Azerbaijan. Here she cuts images of the Mukhtarov Palace, a late-19th century Venetian Gothic building in the country’s capital Baku, with a photograph of the exhibition’s setting, the Palazzo Barbaro in Venice, once owned by a 15th-century Azeri-speaking diplomat Photograph: Almagul Menlibayeva/Yarat Contemporary Art Centre, The Calvert Journal
displayImages.credit: Almagul Menlibayeva/Yarat Contemporary Art Centre, The Calvert Journal
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Almagul Menlibayeva, Azerbaijan
Menlibayeva draws on long-forgotten links between Venice and Azerbaijan. Here she cuts images of the Mukhtarov Palace, a late-19th century Venetian Gothic building in the country’s capital Baku, with a photograph of the exhibition’s setting, the Palazzo Barbaro in Venice, once owned by a 15th-century Azeri-speaking diplomat
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Almagul Menlibayeva/Yarat Contemporary Art Centre, The Calvert Journal

displayImages.caption:
Carmen Dobre, Romania
Consuming History is a photographic series set in a Soviet bunker, documenting visitors being questioned by actors. Blending fact and fiction, many of Dobre’s interrogators are ex-KGB officers while the room itself was built in 1984 as a safe haven from the threat of a nuclear attack Photograph: Carmen Dobre/The Calvert Journal
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Carmen Dobre, Romania
Consuming History is a photographic series set in a Soviet bunker, documenting visitors being questioned by actors. Blending fact and fiction, many of Dobre’s interrogators are ex-KGB officers while the room itself was built in 1984 as a safe haven from the threat of a nuclear attack

displayImages.caption:
Yevgenia Belorusets, Ukraine
Belorusets focuses on the miners who live and work in eastern Ukrainian but have refused to participate in the conflict, opting instead to stay put and carry on with their jobs. Shrouding their faces in clouds of smoke, Belorusets’s images retain the miners’ anonymity but brings their existence to the fore Photograph: Yevgenia Belorusets/The Calvert Journal
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Yevgenia Belorusets, Ukraine
Belorusets focuses on the miners who live and work in eastern Ukrainian but have refused to participate in the conflict, opting instead to stay put and carry on with their jobs. Shrouding their faces in clouds of smoke, Belorusets’s images retain the miners’ anonymity but brings their existence to the fore

displayImages.caption:
JAŠA, Slovenia
Slovenian artist JAŠA presents a week-long script which his team will repeat 28 times until the pavilion closes in November, a project inspired by a quote from Stéphane Hessel, once a member of the French resistance, who said: ‘To create is to resist. To resist is to create’ Photograph: JAŠA & Rosa Lux/The Calvert Journal
displayImages.cleanCaption:
JAŠA, Slovenia
Slovenian artist JAŠA presents a week-long script which his team will repeat 28 times until the pavilion closes in November, a project inspired by a quote from Stéphane Hessel, once a member of the French resistance, who said: ‘To create is to resist. To resist is to create’
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: JAŠA & Rosa Lux/The Calvert Journal

displayImages.caption:
Ivan Grubanov, Serbia
Grubanov has long collected ‘dead flags’ from countries and territories that no longer exist, or have changed form. Here, his installation includes the banner of his native country, the former Yugoslavia, treated in chemicals to produce various paintings and sculptures Photograph: The Calvert Journal
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Ivan Grubanov, Serbia
Grubanov has long collected ‘dead flags’ from countries and territories that no longer exist, or have changed form. Here, his installation includes the banner of his native country, the former Yugoslavia, treated in chemicals to produce various paintings and sculptures

displayImages.caption:
Irina Nakhova, Russia
Nakhova explores Russia’s history between isolation and globalisation. The first woman to represent Russia at the biennale, critics have called her installation ‘devastatingly direct’. Her exhibition was not without controversy though: in the opening week a group of Ukrainian artists and activists staged a mock occupation, crowding the venue in camouflage fatigues Photograph: The Calvert Journal
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Irina Nakhova, Russia
Nakhova explores Russia’s history between isolation and globalisation. The first woman to represent Russia at the biennale, critics have called her installation ‘devastatingly direct’. Her exhibition was not without controversy though: in the opening week a group of Ukrainian artists and activists staged a mock occupation, crowding the venue in camouflage fatigues

displayImages.caption:
Rashad Alakbarov, Azerbaijan
Shown at the Yarat Contemporary Art Centre’s Union of Fire and Water event, Rashad Alakbarov’s work is inspired by the Palazzo Barbaro’s 14th-century Gothic interior, a building once owned by an Azeri-speaking diplomat Photograph: Rashad Alakbarov/Yarat Contemporary Art Centre, The Calvert Journal
displayImages.credit: Rashad Alakbarov/Yarat Contemporary Art Centre, The Calvert Journal
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Rashad Alakbarov, Azerbaijan
Shown at the Yarat Contemporary Art Centre’s Union of Fire and Water event, Rashad Alakbarov’s work is inspired by the Palazzo Barbaro’s 14th-century Gothic interior, a building once owned by an Azeri-speaking diplomat
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Rashad Alakbarov/Yarat Contemporary Art Centre, The Calvert Journal

displayImages.caption:
Dainius Liškevičius, Lithuania
Liškevičius’s presentation is a modern-day cabinet of curiosities consisting of film, images and books that draw on the history of protest in the country, and look at the relationship between activism and art

A version of this gallery first appeared in The Calvert Journal, a guide to the New East Photograph: Arturas Valiauga/The Calvert Journal
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Dainius Liškevičius, Lithuania
Liškevičius’s presentation is a modern-day cabinet of curiosities consisting of film, images and books that draw on the history of protest in the country, and look at the relationship between activism and art

A version of this gallery first appeared in The Calvert Journal, a guide to the New East

cards.title: Cannes / Stars walk the red carpet

item.title: Cannes kicks off: stars walk the red carpet at start of the 2015 film festival
item.trailText: Catherine Deneuve, Julianne Moore, Natalie Portman and Lupita Nyong’o were among those rubbing shoulders with jurors Jake Gyllenhaal and the Coen brothers on the opening night of this year’s Cannes film festival
item.standFirst:
Catherine Deneuve, Julianne Moore, Natalie Portman and Lupita Nyong’o were among those rubbing shoulders with jurors Jake Gyllenhaal and the Coen brothers on the opening night of this year’s Cannes film festival

  • News: Deneuve slams social media while Coens reject TV

cards.title: Hundreds of migrants rescued from boats off Indonesia say they hope to make it to Australia
cards.rawTitle: Hundreds of migrants rescued from boats off Indonesia say they hope to make it to Australia

item.title: Hundreds of migrants rescued from boats off Indonesia say they hope to make it to Australia
item.trailText: Almost 600 migrants from Burma and Bangladesh are being housed in a sports hall in Indonesia's northern Aceh Province
item.standFirst: Almost 600 migrants from Burma and Bangladesh are being housed in a sports hall in Indonesia's northern Aceh province. They spent more than two months at sea before being rescued off the Indonesian coast. Some hope to eventually get to Australia, though for now officials will move them to a bigger site nearby with better sanitation

stillImage.caption: Migrants in Indonesia from Burma wait to be relocated. 14 May 2015 Photograph: Reuters Photograph: Reuters
stillImage.cleanCaption: Migrants in Indonesia from Burma wait to be relocated. 14 May 2015 Photograph: Reuters

displayImages.caption: Migrants in Indonesia from Burma wait to be relocated. 14 May 2015 Photograph: Reuters Photograph: Reuters
displayImages.cleanCaption: Migrants in Indonesia from Burma wait to be relocated. 14 May 2015 Photograph: Reuters

cards.title: Juliette Binoche / I've never been part of the system
cards.rawTitle: I've never been part of the system

item.title: Clouds of Sils Maria star Juliette Binoche: 'I've never been part of the system' – video interview
item.trailText: The star of Olivier Assayas's drama, about an actor crumbling into insecurity, talks to Benjamin Lee about navigating Hollywood
item.standFirst: Clouds of Sils Maria, directed by Olivier Assayas, stars Juliette Binoche as a film actor battling insecurity after a hot young star is offered the key role in a new adaptation of the play that made her famous. Binoche talks to Benjamin Lee about navigating Hollywood, having Kristen Stewart play her on-screen assistant and her relationship with her real-life assistant of 20 years. Clouds of Sils Maria is released in the UK on Friday 15 May and is on limited release in the US and Australia

stillImage.caption: 620x372 trailpic for Clouds of Sils Maria Photograph: guardian.co.uk

cards.title: Prince Harry performs the haka in New Zealand
cards.rawTitle: Prince Harry performs the haka in New Zealand

item.title: Prince Harry performs the Maori haka in New Zealand
item.trailText: Prince Harry performs the Maori haka on Wednesday during his five day trip to New Zealand
item.standFirst: Prince Harry performs the Maori haka on Wednesday during his five day trip to New Zealand. War haka were originally performed by warriors before a battle, proclaiming their strength and prowess in order to intimidate the opposition. The traditional ceremony was part of a day of activities for Harry at Linton military camp, the largest army base in New Zealand

displayImages.caption: 620x372 trailpic for Harry Photograph: guardian.co.uk
displayImages.cleanCaption: 620x372 trailpic for Harry
